description.narrative: This project result framework was developed by Oxfam in Cambodia NRG team in consultation with NGOs partners. It provides the analysis of the most update context regarding politic environment, policy change, civic spaces, and stakeholder and power relations. Thisproject will be implemented by Oxfam in Cambodia, and subsequently finance agreements will be issued to partners namely Developmentand Partnership in Action (DPA) and Highlander Association HA by Oxfam Cambodia to implement relevant activities. Despite EI sectorin Cambodia has not yet developed to the level that significantly contributes to socio-economic development in the country, the sector is emerged as very significant . This is signified from the fact that 61 exploration licenses and 23 exploitation licenses were granted by the end of 2017. According to informal source from the Ministry of Mines and Energy, foreign direct investment in EI sector in Cambodia is estimated about 1.1 billion USD in 2018 and would expect to increase up to 1.3 billion USD in 2019. However, the country faces some issues and challenges in ensuring good governance of the sectors. Lack of quality EIA reports and of transparency in licensing processes is one of key issues. In addition, the way that adecision is made on licensing is very much top down approachwith limited voice and participation from CSO and potential affected communities including indigenous people and women. CSO space become more shrinking. Accor ding to CIVICUs, Cambodia CSO space is considered as # repressed# given the political intimidations and LANGO that were adopted by the government since 2015. Grant Identification Grant Identification - Part 2 Grant Overview DocuSign Envelope ID: 93F17A9A-E9F9-4E8F-82E6-13750B8449A4 Oxfam Project Agreement for Unrestricted Funding April 2017 Page 20 of 35 In addition, Cambodia lacks of relevant policies and procedures concerning social and environmental management. The key concerns of Oxfam are corruption, lack of transparency and accountability, lack of voice from vulnerable people, limited CSO space, and lack of effective policies and operational procedures following international standards by government Ministries and mining companies However, over thepast years, Oxfamtogether with other partners have managed to open up the CSO space in EI sector through initiation and participation in multi-stakeholder dialogues, strengthening CSO network on social and environmental impacts and on indigenous people rights. The recent country impact evaluation of Oxfam investment in EI sector in Cambodia noted significant roles and contributions of Oxfam EI projects to the changes that have emerged. Among them, the draft evaluation report highlights the followings: # The Oxfam EIproject has played a leading role in empowering EI affected communities, most notably through support to Community Mining Focal points # Oxfam was key in MME in setting up Extractive Industry Governance Forum, which provides a multi-stakeholder platform through which civil society observations and inputs can be delivered to government and leading companies. # However, despite significant achievementgiven current political context, Oxfam efforts are helping position civil society to engage and influence national level thinking, but little evidence of this translating to local level impact or action # An example of a CSO network working effectively was the case of LNGO and local communities working at local, national and regional levels to pressure HAGL. In this regard, Oxfam in Cambodia will continue to position Oxfam#s values added with concerned stakeholders including International NGOs and NGO partners, government ministries and selected mining company. Oxfam in Cambodia will deliver outputs which include: 1) nurture CSOs spaces in the dialogues with key stakeholder and to promote multi stakeholder engagement and dialogues 2) identify and engage with selected mining companies to monitor and influence their policy and practices change on social and environmental performances 3) engage with government ministries to secure spaces, and position Oxfam and NGO partners to improve transparency, social and environmental policies and miningcompanies social and environmental performances. CSOs# role and collaboration are recognized by the government at national and subnational level in multi-stakeholder engagement and policy dialogues to enhance social and environmental performance in EI sector. Oxfam will support DPA to coordinate the establishment of multi-stakeholder dialogues in Ratanakiri, Mondulkiri and Preah Vihea province. Oxfam expects that DPA will promote the discussion on responsible mining, CSR, FPIC and Public Participation principles with mining companies and sub national government institutions. It is expected that DPA will coordinate NGOs in each of province to build cases and influencing strategies especially with HA in Ratanakiri province. The target EI companies act in accordance with law/policieson EIA and responsible investment to ensure benefit sharing of concerned communities. DPA has developed EIA checklist to serve as tools to review EIA reports of mining companies, and monitor mining companies implementation of and compliance to Environmental Management Plan (EMP). In addition to that, Oxfam will support DPA to lead the coordination on the review of EI related policies with their respective EISEI network members. Finally, on the engagement with DocuSign Envelope ID: 93F17A9A-E9F9-4E8F-82E6-13750B8449A4 Oxfam Project Agreement for Unrestricted Funding April 2017 Page 21 of 35 mining companies, Oxfam will help DPA to secure certain level of respects and openness with Angkor gold and Mesco gold, so the project will continue to support DPA in nurturing the spaces. Develop capacity (knowledge and skills) of HA staff, IP mining focal points (MFPs) and community members and strengthen coordination of existing IP network and 7 associations to monitor and demand for the respect of IP rights. HA willcontinue to develop capacity of IP mining focal points and community members as HA seek to build strong indigenous community to monitor and challenges mining companiesperformance on the respect of their rights and its practices on social and environmental safeguards. The project will get IP communities of 16 villages well informed and organized to assert their rights following FPIC principles by facilitating communities to define their community protocol on community consultation and agreement following FPIC principles. Document good practice on community negotiation experiences in dealing with HAGL and strengthening existing networks representatives in mining areas in order to pilot the negotiation with Angkor Gold. The project will facilitateHA#s initiative to document experiences related to community negotiationwith HAGL company. HA will learn such experiences and replicate within their target villages especially where Angkor Gold concession areas located in. The project will also allow Oxfam in Cambodia to continue its support to NGO partners as the following: # Provide technical supports to partners to secure CSOs# spaces, visibility and credibility with mining companies, MoME, MOE in EIGF # Provide technical and institutional development supports to partner to ensure grant compliances, and project deliverables # Engage and influences government institutions like MoE and MoME to secure spaces for CSOs engagement in policy development related to social and environment safeguards,key performance indicators, planning, EIA and licensing processes # Initiate and engage in multi stakeholder visits and monitoring mechanisms to enhance social, environmental performance and compliances.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project#s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: Strengthened CSOs: # CSOs increasingly participate in or initiate influencing towards small scale producers land rights and access to water and/or more inclusive land and/or water governance processes (following Oxfam Novib/partners actions)
